Re #34 response: Andy, you simply misrepresent Susan Solomon when you say that her use of "flattening" (referring to a declining trend) is the same as your use of "plateau" (referring to the absence of a trend). The abstract from the paper eliminates all doubt:

"Stratospheric water vapor concentrations decreased by about 10% after the year 2000. Here, we show that this acted to slow the rate of increase in global surface temperature over 2000 to 2009 by about 25% compared to that which would have occurred due only to carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases. More limited data suggest that stratospheric water vapor probably increased between 1980 and 2000, which would have enhanced the decadal rate of surface warming during the 1990s by about 30% compared to estimates neglecting this change. These findings show that stratospheric water vapor represents an important driver of decadal global surface climate change."

And from the NOAA press release: "The findings might help explain why global surface temperatures have not risen as fast in the last ten years as they did in the 1980s and 1990s."

Re your front page CRU story, it's true that where there's smoke there's often fire, but in this case it was more like someone standing at a broken window behind the building with a smoke generator and a fan. You should have been able to tell the difference, which is to say you should have waited for actual evidence of impropriety before doing a story that so strongly implied that there must have been some. A story about the hack and its possible motivations would have been in order, even though it wouldn't have made the front page.

You win! You've successfully denied what science including climate science has been telling you about overpopulation, overconsumption and their effects including climate change, species loss, peak oil and all other resource depletion!

What do you win? Generations of unprecedented misery! Congratulations!

Nick #41, you have put a lot of stuff there and I will try to deal with some of it.

I don’t bother with Benson’s comments because most of them are not intelligent in my opinion, but evidently he got you confused. Here is what you say about Benson’s comment. “If the signal from the hypothesis is statistically significant this provides confirmation of the hypothesis… Treating the other factors as noise, the anthropogenic signal shows up clearly by using 30 or more years of data…So, on many grounds, we have a highly confirmed hypothesis regarding the role of CO2. It is part of (but not all of) a quite good understanding of climate.” First of all I don’t know what he means by signal from the hypothesis. What signal, what hypothesis? Hypotheses don’t produce signals. In any case assuming he simply misspoke about climate, the other factors are not noise and one cannot treat them as such. Climate is complex and there is much coupling and feedback; and disputes about positive and negative. The point is that the other factors are not simply noise. There may be other drivers like sunspots, plate motion, and changes in ocean currents. They are coupled. He just wants to ignore them and average them out so the CO2 signal stands out there alone. What a joke!

No, I do not trust the scientists involved. Some of them have demonstrated beyond doubt that they are untrustworthy. So you want me to assume that all the others are trustworthy? In any case the economic implications of climate science are so enormous, for example grants, that many nominally honest scientists succumb and are being corrupted. Too bad for the honest scientists; they should speak out; then we would know who they are.

“From a more intuitive position, what do you make of the Vostok ice core analysis; and what if we superimpose business-as-usual CO2 scenarios onto that graph? Is there potential warming beyond typical interglacial maximums that we should be concerned about?” The Vostok data exhibits many major elements related to Earth’s orbit perturbations. Ignore those; the origin is well known. Look in great detail with a resolution of a hundred of year and you will see a few substantial warming and cooling cycles within every thousand year period, virtually identical to what we have observed during the past 1000 years and clearly deriving from the same basic source; sunspots. However, look at the CO2 data. It is clearly a trailing average of the temperature data but with a time constant of maybe a few hundred years, much smoother, so it clearly is not driving but rather resulting from the sunspot driven warming. It illustrates the coupling that makes the Benson assertion so ridiculous.

I have never asserted that the case for AGW is all handwaving. I believe, I emphasize it is my opinion, I am not asserting, that CO2 does play a role, it is one of the players, but it is not dominant. The assertion of a specific numerical relationship between CO2 concentration increase and global average temperature, in my not so humble opinion, is ludicrous. No one knows yet and anyone who claims they know the constant is either stupid or a liar. So in my personal opinion, Hansen has proven himself to be one or the other. In contrast, I have not been making predictions; just asserting my beliefs.

“What about the potential for shorter-term threshold effects and rapid warming that the poor in particular are not prepared to adapt to?” If that happens, although there is little historical evidence of that, the poor as always will get the short end of the stick. The focus should be to eliminate poverty; we have a better chance of doing that than eliminating CO2 emissions. Both are a matter of broadband will power, and neither is likely to happen.

On the issue of science and the purity of the conclusions drawn, you keep ignoring that the work is not being done in a vacuum by pure, dedicated scientists immune to personal benefits from skewing or misrepresenting the data or the science. Again I say there are many good and honest scientists but there are also many lowlights. If I had a way of distinguishing that would be great. Only a handful of low lights are quite apparent. I have no idea about the rest except they are not speaking out and that makes me suspicious. Even in a field as innocuous as lasers, which I knew very well, it was incredible how many lowlights and low beams I ran into. Nick; please don’t lecture me about purity of the breed.

Here's another line from the Solomon paper:

"However, the trend in global surface temperatures has been nearly flat since the late 1990s despite continuing increases in the forcing due to the sum of the well-mixed greenhouse gases (CO2, CH4, halocarbons, and N2O), raising questions regarding the understanding of forced climate change, its drivers, the parameters that define natural internal variability (2), and how fully these terms are represented in climate models."

Critics of that article of mine last year also tend to ignore this sentence setting the recent temperatures -- whether you call them a plateau, a stall, a flutter, etc... -- in context:

"Scientists say the pattern of the last decade — after a precipitous rise in average global temperatures in the 1990s — is a result of cyclical variations in ocean conditions and has no bearing on the long-term warming effects of greenhouse gases building up in the atmosphere."

Andy Revkin --- First, using global tempeatures, the just past decade was the warmest of the instrumental period. Here is a link with NOAA's latest graphic:
http://climateprogress.org...
which clearly indicates a lack of flattening. Second, Solomon et al. observed a decadal flattening in the tropical SSTs between 10N and 10S latitude. While the tropical ocean is indeed vast, it is but a fraction of the entire globe. This regional time series is not comperable to the global temperature product.

Solomon et al. make a very good, although in the scheme of things minor, point. But the paper should not be misconstrued to indicate more than another source of variation laid upon the obvious underlying trend. For further analysis of the latter, do see several fairly recent threads on Tamino's Open Mind blog.

As an English-speaker in Germany, just beginning to learn German, I've spent a fair bit of time trying the various automated translation tools that are available. German to English is actually a fairly easy test for this type of software, as the two languages are in many respects similar. I can report that the technology is not there yet.

As a test, copy a sentence from your column into Google translate, translate it into German, then copy the result and let the software translate back into English.

Most sentences are rendered into grammatically awkward, idiomatically flawed and information-challenged ruins of their former selves. Yahoo's babelfish is even worse. I haven't found any software that can pass even this simple test, so effortless communication across languages, instant or not, is still Sci-Fi.

Despite 50 years of research and $400 billion of funding, there is still no cure for cancer, nor a basic understanding of what causes it. There are, however, empirical techniques for mitigating the effects and the death rate for specific types of cancer. Many are not optimistic about the potential fruits of cancer research. It appears it will go on interminably. Similarly, the credibility of climate science has taken some serious blows and public confidence in predictions is diminishing. A BBC poll shows that the number of Brits skeptical of climate science is rising, http://news.bbc.co.uk...

Global warming is probably a more difficult problem to resolve than cancer and it is almost certain that we will never be able to predict global average surface temperature even if manmade CO2 emissions are eliminated and the concentration returns to the nominal 280 ppm for this current period of the Milankovitch cycle. I assert that because we will never be able to predict sunspot counts, tectonic plate motion, ocean current changes, surface albedo changes, etc. all of which contribute. Nevertheless, the issue at hand is temperature change related to CO2 concentration change and I have been thinking about how to establish the relationship between the related component of global average temperature (GAST) change and CO2 concentration change. If we had that insight and it was credible most or all of the skepticism would disappear and we would be able to get on with resolving the problem if appropriate.

One way to do a meaningful experiment is to suddenly decrease the worldwide CO2 concentration by a small amount say 5 - 10 ppm and observe the change in global average surface temperature as a function of time for some period afterward. One can expect a decrease in the GAST in response to the concentration decrease followed by additional changes caused by coupled phenomena. The related changes would be revealed in response to the GAST change, hence a great deal could be learned from a carefully planned and executed experiment. No doubt it would be a very expensive experiment by virtue of all the monitoring and of course reducing the CO2 concentration would be non trivial. Some smart geoengineering people are thinking about how to capture and sequester CO2. It is an experiment that probably could be done and if done credibly would end all the debate and the cynicism. Nothing left to do but watch the Superbowl and the head crashing.
